content:
Also...when you say "delete from profile", am I correct that you mean to delete the "all mail" folder from the Profile directory? I just looked through Thunderbird's "Account Settings" and don't see an option to not have "all mail" so am I correct to assume that I just have to keep deleting the All Mail folder?

Thank you.
creator: TOBrienArchitect

content: AllMail is a tool, primarily for Gmail itself. In reality, there is only one folder in gmail, Allmail. When accessing gmail online, that one folder does it all. What you 'see' as folders in Thunderbird, such as inbox, sent, trash, etc. are just subsets. To make it work logically, Thunderbird (and all other email clients) have to artificially make real folders to imitate what Gmail is doing. As such the overhead is doubled, cpu time, elapsed time, and storage space. Allmail has a copy of all mail, so it serves you in no way when using Thunderbird. The recommendation from Thunderbird is to unsubscribe and then to delete .

content:
Se vai in Tasto menu > Impostazioni account > NOME_ACCOUNT > Sincronizzazione e archiviazione trovi le seguenti impostazioni Per recuperare spazio su disco è possibile eliminare definitivamente i vecchi messaggi, sia le copie locali sia quelle memorizzate nel server remoto. [ ] Non eliminare alcun messaggio [ ] Elimina tutti eccetto i [ ] Elimina i messaggi più vecchi di

Non eliminare alcun messaggio è l'impostazione predefinita quando configuri l'account. Elimina tutti eccetto i... e Elimina i messaggi più vecchi di... permettono di cancellare i messaggi più vecchi ma vanno attivati volontariamente dall'utente.

Piuttosto, il problema potrebbe essere legato all'uso di IMAP. Se oltre a Thunderbird accedi anche da altri dispositivi (browser, smartphone, app, etc.) potrebbe essere stato una di questi ad innescare la cancellazione. Per come è fatto IMAP quello che fai in un singolo dispositivo viene immediatamente replicato sul server e poi propagato agli altri client appena si collegano.

creator: sfhowes

content:
Je možné, že už je preplnený priečinok "Doručená pošta" kde je Thunderbirdom stanovený maximálny objem 4GB (rovnako ako aj pre každý samostatný priečinok). Kliknite na priečinok "Doručená pošta" pravým tlačidlom myši, vyberte "Vlastnosti" a preverte akú veľkosť na disku zaberá. Limit veľkosti zložky je detailnejšie vysvetlený tuná: http://kb.mozillazine.org/Limits_%28Thunderbird%29#Folders_and_messages.

Odporúčam staré správy z preplneného priečinka "Doručená pošta" a "Odoslaná pošta" odstrániť, alebo archivovať. Postup archivácie: Označte všetku starú poštu v priečinku "Doručená pošta" (cca 1000 emailov) a zvoľte a (stlačiť klávesu a), alebo ich po označení archivujte aj takto (druhá možnosť): - Thunderbird - Správa - Archivovať - všetka stará pošta je ARCHIVOVANÁ - nájdete ju v priečinku ARCHÍVY pod konkrétnym letopočtom. Poštu z roku 2022 archivuje do priečinka 2022. Poštu z roku 2023 archivuje do priečinka 2023...atď https://support.mozilla.org/cs/kb/archivace-zprav

Pokiaľ v Thunderbirde odstránite e-mail, tak sa v skutočnosti iba označí ako odstránený, ale fyzicky zostane. Jeho fyzické odstránenie sa vykoná až použitím voľby "Údržbu priečinkov“. Takže aby ste zmenšili veľkosť preplneného priečinka je nutné ešte vykonať "Údržba priečinkov": https://support.mozilla.org/cs/kb/provedeni-udrzby-slozek. POSTUP: - Thunderbird - Súbor - Vykonať údržbu priečinkov http://imgbank.cz/images/2015/08/19/Thunderbird_udrzba_priecinkov.jpg

Ďalšou možnosťou je, že ste narazili na limit veľkosti niektorého iného priečinka, kde je maximálny limit tak isto 4GB. V tomto prípade pomôže to isté - uvolniť preplnený priečinok archiváciou, alebo odstránením starých správ, a následným spustením "Údržby priečinkov".

content:
I'm not going to take responsibility for telling you how to re-install Thunderbird but will give you this advise: If you've got e-mails or anything else on your computer that you value you should have a backup copy. Hard disks can fail and modern solid state ones tend to give less warning before they expire than mechanical ones. There are plenty of other things that can delete or corrupt data so it's best to be prepared.

It may be an old cliché but it's still true: "Data you only have one copy of is data you don't care about."

content: It may be that the prefs.js file (the one that keeps the settings) is not being updated when thunderbird closes. That may be happening due to an antivirus or other software running.You can check that by exploring the profile to see if there are multiple versions of the prefs file, such as prefs-1.js, prefs-2.js. Click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folder', click 'open folder' and you will be in the profile. exit thunderbird if you are considering making any changes. Look to see if there are multiple prefs.js files. If so, I suggest, - deleting prefs.js and all other prefs.js files except the one with highest number. Rename that one to prefs.js and restart thunderbird.

content:
Wayne is correct - it looks like folders B and E have a folder flag set up as 'Drafts'

Once you have installed folderFlags addon You right clickon eg: E folder and select 'Properties' Then uncheck the 'Drafts' option. click on 'OK'

I've provided an image as a guide. In the example I'm talking about the Inbox, but same process applies to any folder. In your case you do not want any of those options selected.

If you need more info on installing the addon pease let us know.

creator: welcome

content:
welcome said
@wsmwk: Thank you. Where is the folder type information stored? In "folder.msf" ? I assume it's difficult to manually edit the file, because it's Mork ?

The problem is this - it's one of those things that is just not obvious - I know where many things are located but this one had me stumped.

Viewing the index file is simple enough you just use a text editor, but that just contains info regarding what is contained in the mbox file. The flag is set against the folder not specific emails. I though it might be in the folderCache.json file.

Although it mentions 'flags' - I would not feel confident about editing anything because you would really need to know what each specific number actually represents.

Pop seem different from imap and also smart mailboxes

Pop: "flags" : 28, seems to be applied to an actual mail account name folder "flags" : 16388, has folder name 'Archives' "flags" : 1028, has folder name 'Drafts' "flags" : 4100, has folder name 'Inbox' "flags" : 1073741828, has folder name 'Junk' "flags" : 516, has folder name 'Sent' "flags" : 4194308, has folder name 'Templates' "flags" : 260, has folder name 'Deleted' (usually seen as 'Trash' in Folder Pane) "flags" : 4, - seems to be applied for a folder I created - so ordinary folder.

smart mailboxes: (Unified Folders) "flags" : 28, has folderName : "Unified Folders", "flags" : 16420, has folderName : "Archives", "flags" : 1060, has folderName : "Drafts", "flags" : 4132, has folderName : "Inbox", "flags" : 1073741860, has folderName : "Junk", "flags" : 548, has folderName : "Sent", "flags" : 4194340, has folderName : "Templates", "flags" : 292, folderName : "Deleted", (usually seen as 'Trash' in Folder Pane) "flags" : 4, - seems to be applied for a folder I created - so ordinary folder.


Imap: "flags" : 0, for imap mail account folder name "flags" : 671621396, set for a default gmail bin/trash folder "flags" : 134751252, set for default gmail folder name 'Drafts' "flags" : 134754324, set for default gmail folder name 'Inbox' "flags" : 134750228, set for a subfolder of Inbox which I created. "flags" : 134750212, set for a subfolder of Inbox which I created. "flags" : 134750228, set for a folder I created "flags" : 134766612, set for a folder I created "flags" : 671621140, set for a folder I created "flags" : 671621652, set for default gmail folder name 'Sent Mail' "flags" : 1745362948, set for default gmail folder name 'Spam' "flags" : 4194308, set for default gmail folder name 'Templates' "flags" : 151527444, seems to be set for a 'noSelect' folder I created


I deliberately set the pop Inbox to have both Inbox and Drafts flag Then after restart, rechecked to see what flag had been set for Inbox.msf Previously: "flags" : 1028, has folder name 'Drafts' "flags" : 4100, has folder name 'Inbox'

After setting additional 'Drafts flag on 'Inbox' "flags" : 5124, has folderName : "Inbox",

Did the same for imap account Previously "flags" : 134751252, set for default gmail folder name 'Drafts' "flags" : 134754324, set for default gmail folder name 'Inbox'

After setting additional 'Drafts flag on 'Inbox' "flags" : 134755348 for default Inbox

After removing the incorrect 'Drafts' and leaving just 'Inbox', restaring Thunderbird, check folderCache.json and the Inbox 'flag' numbers have reverted to original setting.

These are my findings, but it would be interesting to know what other people see. I'm not suggesting any editing of the folderCache.json file at this point because this is just my observations - if you wish to try then please make a backup of the original before you edit anything.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: I don't advocate nor advise people hacking files by direct editing, nor will I provide this information. Standard tools should be used where possible. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/ is one such tool
creator: wsmwk

content:
Wayne Mery said
I don't advocate nor advise people hacking files by direct editing, nor will I provide this information. Standard tools should be used where possible. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/ is one such tool


I'm in agreement with you, as I said " I'm not suggesting any editing of the folderCache.json file" because you have to know what you are doing.

I have always advised people in the Thunderbird Support Forum to use the addon 'folderFlags' because it is the easiest and safest method to check and fix flags set on folders.

In a bugzilla post this was advised....folderCache.json should not be removed, since it will cause TB to visit all folders in the system which can be problematic for large profiles with many folders. You can edit the JSON file in an editor correcting or removing incorrect entries.

Hence, it is better to have a good understanding of the contents of the 'folderCache.json' file and that is normally obtained by sharing information by willing users.

As the person who posted the question enquired about which file and what data would need to be edited if the user did not want to use an addon, it's necessary to have a better understanding what the 'flags' means and whether the information I see is also seen by others. But if anyone does not want to participate then that's ok. I'm not demanding information just asking for others to volunteer information.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: @Toad-Hall : I completely agree with you. Thanks for looking into this. If we can find an obvious method to manually edit the affected file(s), I'd have more trust in this for this specific task than in an add-on, which may have bugs just as Thunderbird itself obviously has a bug which causes this specific behaviour.
creator: welcome

content:
@Toad-Hall : Worked like a charm! The stubbornly undeletable draft folders indeed had flag 1028 which I changed to flag 4. The folders are now deletable, problem solved. Thank you so much!

And sorry for not having found this obvious solution myself, I should have looked more closely into the files.
creator: welcome

content:
To clarify - not disagreeing with Toad-Hall. My comment about not editing files was directed at the reporter, and to any user who is tempted to edit files. This is normally a bad idea in any part of Thunderbird, not just folder files - too many users shoot themselves in the foot by doing such things and then ask for assistance to resolve their now worse problem.

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/ is maintained by a reputable developer who definitely knows what they are doing. I can personally confirm that it has worked over many years and never caused any problems.

In the distant past it was possible for add-ons to break Thunderbird, but this is much less likely to happen in recent years - we have a robust add-on review process, and a full time developer dedicated to providing the code infrastructure for add-ons, and assisting authors in proper techniques. If anyone has had problems with an add-on breaking Thunderbird in the last year or two that might be worth filing a bug report.
creator: wsmwk

content:
Thanks for the helpful response. Once I knew to click on the three dots, with a little trial and error, I figured out that turning on "Total Message Count", it would show the total messages. Since my practice when looking at Spam messages is to either delete them or move them to a valid folder, a count other than zero will indicate there's something I ought to look at. I've attached some before and after screen shots in case that might help anybody else with the same problem.

But I don't understand why the Spam folder can't behave the way I THINK the other folders behave even when "Total Message Count" is off. That is they show the total # of UNREAD messages. Only with the Spam folder, you must click on it to get the total # of unread messages to appear. The Catch-22 is that without that memory jogger, I don't always remember to click on it, and didn't get a message about an appointment today until too late.

But hopefully now, because of your help, I won't miss any more important messages that are mouldering in the Spam folder. So thanks a bunch!!
creator: MandyWh

content:
Right click the folder, select properties and then select "when getting new messages for this account, always check this folder."

Thunderbird does not by default check the trash or the spam folders when getting new mail, only when you select the folder. So, yes it does not work like the other folders, or like you expect it to work. unless you change the defaults to make it act like other folders.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thanks for the very helpful info. I guess there's a reason that all the parameters for Thunderbird (and practically every other program I used) are scattered here, there and everywhere, you can't set (and keep) the behaviours you want. (Windows does a masterful job of reorganizing the Control Panel every 15 minutes to make it as difficult as possible to override their nitwit defaults. [g])

And actually there was a piece of serendipity from your advice. Every so often, when Thunderbird compresses folders, it garbles messages (e.g. the wrong recipient will be attached to a message). I had been about to post a query asking whether anybody was aware of this and/or had suggestions for what to do about it. But when I right clicked to follow your advice, I discovered the repair function and after I ran it, the message in which I notice the error had the correct recipient again.

So double-thanks for your help.
creator: MandyWh

content: File/New/Saved Search..., create a saved search and add the desired folders. Press Alt if the Menu Bar with File is hidden.
creator: sfhowes

content:
The previous instance of TB, 128.1.1, was installed in a different location under C:\Program FIles\WindowsApps\Mozilla Thunderbird.

Simply delete the old TB program version using Windows Explorer. It will not touch your existing profile. Having said that, it's always recommended to create a full profile backup on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile

Note, you should avoid starting different versions of Thunderbird with the same profile.

creator: christ1

content:
If you open the settings and scroll about two-thirds of the way down you'll find the 'Reading & Display' section. In that is a tick-box to "Close message window/tab on move or delete." Ticking that should provide your second choice.

As for opening the next oldest, do you have them sorted with the oldest at the top of the list or the newest? Reversing that may get what you want.
creator: ThePillenwerfer

content: To make the next newer message open after deleting, Settings/General, Config. editor, toggle mail.delete_matches_sort_order to true.
creator: sfhowes

In the profile folder/map.

If you have set up or having that file the file the parent.lock in your profile folder, you can see it as leaving and starting up your Thunderbird software, that it is restarted /closed every time, because running these parts of data in or off this process, this software Thunderbird sometimes unfortunately cannot start itself, there are also other issues that can show these causes as described.

You can if you like follow these steps and erase and delete them .so after that this process and steps ,the program can restart itself again.

In the same profile folder, try to delete the following data: parent.lock old parent.lock session.json xulstore.json

Is it possible to do that? So we can solve that issue of you re computer pc?
